title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Factor analysis one widely used methods social behavioural sciences. single latent factor fits covariance among set observed indicators, researchers often treat latent variable causally relevant quantity subsequent analyses. practice implicitly assumes structural interpretation latent factor model: latent variable , rather individual indicators, causally efficacious. measurement model fits well guarantee structural interpretation correct. indicators direct causal effects outcome, even though covariance structure perfectly consistent single latent factor. structural interpretation wrong, causal conclusions treating latent variable cause may misleading. VanderWeele Vansteelandt (2022) showed structural interpretation imposes testable empirical constraints. structest package implements two statistical tests—\(T_0\) \(T_1\)—can reject constraints, providing researchers principled way evaluate whether structural interpretation tenable.

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Consider reflective latent factor model \(d\) indicators: \[ X_i = \mu_i + \lambda_i\,\eta + \varepsilon_i, \qquad = 1, \ldots, d \] \(\eta\) latent variable, \(\lambda_i\) factor loadings (reliabilities), \(\mu_i\) intercepts, \(\varepsilon_i\) independent error terms. structural interpretation, latent variable \(\eta\) causally relevant quantity. external variable \(Z\) affects \(\eta\) (indicators \(\eta\)), Theorem 1 VanderWeele Vansteelandt (2022), indicators \(\), \(j\) values \(z\), \(z^*\): \[ \lambda_i \bigl\{E(X_j \mid Z=z) - E(X_j \mid Z=z^*)\bigr\} = \lambda_j \bigl\{E(X_i \mid Z=z) - E(X_i \mid Z=z^*)\bigr\} \] identity testable observed data. \(T_0\) \(T_1\) tests formalise using generalised methods moments estimators (Newey & McFadden, 1994).

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: \(T_0\) test (Section 3.2 paper) models conditional expectations : \[ E(X_i \mid Z = z_j) = \gamma_i + \frac{\lambda_i}{\lambda_1}\,\beta_j \] \(\beta_1 = 0\) (reference level). gives \(d \times p\) moment conditions \(d + p - 1\) free parameters, yielding \((d-1)(p-1)\) degrees freedom. test requires estimated reliability coefficients \(\lambda_i\), obtained pairwise covariances via quasi-Poisson GLM. use: \(d \geq 3\) indicators \(p \geq 2\) levels \(Z\).

what: Example: data consistent with the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: data generated structural model, test statistic small \(p\)-value large—fail reject \(H_0\).
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 5  # Simulate under the structural model z <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5)                        # binary auxiliary variable eta <- 1 + 0.5 * z + rnorm(n)                 # latent factor affected by Z lambda <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9, 0.7)         # factor loadings X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- 2 + lambda[i] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  # T0 test (should NOT reject) result_t0 <- test_t0(X, z) print(result_t0) #>  #>   T0: Reliability-dependent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X and z  #> statistic = 6.075, df = 4, p-value = 0.1936 #> n = 5000, d = 5 indicators, p = 2 Z-levels

what: Example: data violating the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Now consider data \(Z\) affects indicator disproportionately, violates structural interpretation: test statistic large \(p\)-value small, correctly rejecting structural interpretation. can inspect full output summary():
code: set.seed(12345) eta <- rnorm(n) X_bad <- cbind(   2 + 1.0 * eta + 0.5 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   3 + 0.8 * eta + 2.0 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   # disproportionate Z effect   1 + 0.6 * eta - 0.3 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   2 + 0.9 * eta + 0.4 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   1 + 0.7 * eta + 0.8 * z + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3) )  # T0 test (should reject) result_t0_bad <- test_t0(X_bad, z) print(result_t0_bad) #>  #>   T0: Reliability-dependent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #> statistic = 2226, df = 4, p-value = < 2.2e-16 #> n = 5000, d = 5 indicators, p = 2 Z-levels summary(result_t0_bad) #>  #>   T0: Reliability-dependent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #>  #> Test statistic:  2226  #> Degrees of freedom:  4  #> P-value:  < 2.2e-16  #>  #> Sample size:  5000  #> Indicators (d):  5  #> Z-levels (p):  2  #> Convergence code:  1  #>  #> Parameter estimates: #>   gamma (intercepts): #>     X1     X2     X3     X4     X5  #> 1.7006 2.7836 0.8274 1.7447 0.7968  #>   beta (Z effects): #>   z=0   z=1  #> 0.000 1.728  #>   lambda (reliabilities): #> [1] 1.0099 1.0213 0.4555 0.9002 0.8222

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: \(T_1\) test (Section 3.3 paper) avoids estimating reliabilities entirely. structural model, conditional expectations satisfy (Equation 3 paper): \[ E(X_i \mid Z = z_j) = \gamma_i + \alpha_i\,\beta_j \] \(\alpha_1 = 1\) identification \(\beta_1 = 0\) reference level. means matrix mean differences \[ \Delta_{ij} = E(X_i \mid Z = z_j) - E(X_i \mid Z = z_1) \] rank \(\leq 1\) structural model. \(T_1\) test checks rank constraint using generalised methods moments, \(d \times p\) moment conditions, \(2d + p - 2\) free parameters, \((d-1)(p-2)\) degrees freedom. use: \(d \geq 3\) indicators \(p \geq 3\) levels \(Z\). Preferred \(T_0\) rely error-structure assumptions needed reliability estimation.

what: Example: data consistent with the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: , test reject—consistent data generated structural model.
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 4  # Simulate under the structural model with a 4-level Z z <- sample(0:3, n, replace = TRUE) eta <- 1 + 0.3 * (z == 1) + 0.7 * (z == 2) + 1.2 * (z == 3) + rnorm(n) lambda <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9) X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- 2 + lambda[i] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  # T1 test (should NOT reject) result_t1 <- test_t1(X, z) print(result_t1) #>  #>   T1: Reliability-independent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X and z  #> statistic = 3.017, df = 6, p-value = 0.8068 #> n = 5000, d = 4 indicators, p = 4 Z-levels

what: Example: data violating the structural model
title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: structural interpretation rejected, expected.
code: set.seed(12345) eta <- rnorm(n) X_bad <- cbind(   2 + 1.0 * eta + 0.5 * (z == 1) + 0.3 * (z == 2) + 0.4 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   3 + 0.8 * eta + 2.0 * (z == 1) + 0.1 * (z == 2) + 3.0 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   1 + 0.6 * eta - 0.3 * (z == 1) + 0.8 * (z == 2) - 0.5 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3),   2 + 0.9 * eta + 0.4 * (z == 1) + 0.6 * (z == 2) + 0.3 * (z == 3)     + rnorm(n, sd = 0.3) )  # T1 test (should reject) result_t1_bad <- test_t1(X_bad, z) print(result_t1_bad) #>  #>   T1: Reliability-independent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #> statistic = 1400, df = 6, p-value = < 2.2e-16 #> n = 5000, d = 4 indicators, p = 4 Z-levels summary(result_t1_bad) #>  #>   T1: Reliability-independent test of structural interpretation (VanderWeele & Vansteelandt, 2022)  #>  #> data:   X_bad and z  #>  #> Test statistic:  1400  #> Degrees of freedom:  6  #> P-value:  < 2.2e-16  #>  #> Sample size:  5000  #> Indicators (d):  4  #> Z-levels (p):  4  #> Convergence code:  1  #>  #> Parameter estimates: #>   gamma (intercepts): #>     X1     X2     X3     X4  #> 2.0874 3.0879 1.0657 2.1165  #>   alpha: #>      X1      X2      X3      X4  #>  1.0000  7.7241 -1.5415  0.6062  #>   beta (Z effects): #>     z=0     z=1     z=2     z=3  #>  0.0000  0.2375 -0.0676  0.3791

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: estimate_reliability() function estimates factor loadings \(\lambda_i\) pairwise covariances. model \(X_i = \mu_i + \lambda_i\,\eta + \varepsilon_i\), \(\text{Cov}(X_i, X_j) = \lambda_i\,\lambda_j\). Taking logs gives \(\log \text{Cov}(X_i, X_j) = \log\lambda_i + \log\lambda_j\), linear model log-reliabilities. function fits quasi-Poisson GLM log link. function called internally test_t0(), can use directly need reliability estimates purposes.
code: set.seed(12345) n <- 5000 d <- 5 eta <- rnorm(n) lambda_true <- c(1.0, 0.8, 0.6, 0.9, 0.7) X <- matrix(NA, n, d) for (i in 1:d) {   X[, i] <- lambda_true[i] * eta + rnorm(n, sd = 0.5) }  rel <- estimate_reliability(X)  # Compare estimated vs true data.frame(   true = lambda_true,   estimated = round(rel$lambda, 3) ) #>   true estimated #> 1  1.0     0.974 #> 2  0.8     0.808 #> 3  0.6     0.594 #> 4  0.9     0.898 #> 5  0.7     0.695

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model
text: Guidance: \(T_1\) generally preferred depend error-structure assumptions needed estimate reliabilities (e.g., independent, homoscedastic errors). \(T_0\) necessary 2 levels \(Z\) available, since \(T_1\) requires \(p \geq 3\). tests applicable (\(d \geq 3\), \(p \geq 3\)), running provides useful sensitivity check. Agreement strengthens conclusion; disagreement may signal misspecification error distribution (affects \(T_0\) \(T_1\)).

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model

text: R package implementing statistical tests : VanderWeele, T. J. & Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 84, 2032–2054. doi:10.1111/rssb.12555

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
text: Factor analysis routinely used assess whether single univariate latent variable explains covariance among set observed indicators. one-factor model fits adequately, researchers often treat latent variable causally relevant quantity subsequent analyses. practice implicitly assumes structural interpretation latent factor model: latent variable, rather individual indicators, causally efficacious. However, measurement model fitting well imply structural interpretation correct. individual indicators separate causal effects outcomes, even though covariance structure consistent single latent factor (see Figures 2 3 paper). VanderWeele Vansteelandt (2022) show structural interpretation empirically testable implications. Specifically, structural latent factor model, association external variable Z indicator X_i, scaled factor loading X_i, must across indicators (Theorem 1). package implements two statistical tests proposed paper: T0: statistical test dependent reliability estimates (Section 3.2) T1: statistical test independent reliability estimates (Section 3.3)

title: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model
Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Univariate Latent Factor Model

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: Estimates reliability coefficients (loadings) \(\lambda_i\) indicator univariate latent factor model, using pairwise covariances quasi-Poisson GLM log link.

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: X numeric matrix (n x d) indicator variables, d >= 3. na.rm logical; TRUE, rows NA removed.

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: list components: lambda numeric vector length d estimated reliabilities. glm_fit fitted glm object. V_k matrix (n x d) per-subject estimating function contributions reliability parameters (used internally test_t0).

title: Estimate Reliability Coefficients (Section 3.1) — estimate_reliability
text: structural model \(X_i = \alpha_i + \lambda_i Y + \varepsilon_i\), \(\mathrm{Cov}(X_i, X_j) = \lambda_i \lambda_j\). log pairwise covariance modelled linear combination \(\log(\lambda_i)\), yielding quasi-Poisson GLM.

title: structest: Testing the Structural Interpretation of a Latent Factor Model — structest-package
text: test_t0 Reliability-dependent test (Section 3.2). Requires d >= 3 indicators p >= 2 Z-levels. test_t1 Reliability-independent test (Section 3.3). Requires d >= 2 indicators p >= 3 Z-levels. estimate_reliability Estimate reliability coefficients via quasi-Poisson GLM (Section 3.1).

what: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: Tests whether structural interpretation univariate latent factor model can rejected, using GMM test accounts uncertainty estimated reliability coefficients.

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
code: test_t0(X, z, na.rm = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: X numeric matrix (n x d) indicator variables, d >= 3. z numeric vector length n encoding auxiliary variable. Must least 2 distinct levels. na.rm logical; TRUE, rows NA removed. verbose logical; TRUE, print progress information.

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: object class c("structest_t0", "structest", "htest") containing: statistic T0 test statistic. parameter degrees freedom, \((d-1)(p-1)\). p.value p-value chi-squared distribution. method description test. data.name name data objects. estimates list gamma (intercepts), beta (Z effects), lambda (reliabilities). n_obs number observations used. d number indicators. p number Z-levels. convergence convergence code nlm. optim_details full output nlm.

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: structural model, \(E[X_i | Z = z_j] = \gamma_i + (\lambda_i / \lambda_1) \beta_j\). gives \(d \times p\) moment conditions \(d + p - 1\) free parameters (\(\gamma_1, \ldots, \gamma_d\) \(\beta_2, \ldots, \beta_p\) \(\beta_1 = 0\)), yielding \((d-1)(p-1)\) degrees freedom. variance GMM estimating equations adjusted uncertainty reliability estimates \(\lambda_i\).

title: T0 Test: Reliability-Dependent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.2) — test_t0
text: VanderWeele, T. J. Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society Series B, 84, 2032–2054.

what: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: Tests whether structural interpretation univariate latent factor model can rejected, without requiring estimation reliability coefficients. Uses centered indicators two-step efficient GMM procedure.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
code: test_t1(X, z, na.rm = TRUE, max_iter = 1000L, tol = 1e-25, verbose = FALSE)

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: X numeric matrix (n x d) indicator variables, d >= 3. z numeric vector length n encoding auxiliary variable. Must least 3 distinct levels. na.rm logical; TRUE, rows NA removed. max_iter integer; maximum iterations alternating LS procedure. tol numeric; convergence tolerance alternating LS procedure. verbose logical; TRUE, print progress information.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: object class c("structest_t1", "structest", "htest") containing: statistic T1 test statistic. parameter degrees freedom, \((d-1)(p-2)\). p.value p-value chi-squared distribution. method description test. data.name name data objects. estimates list alpha beta. n_obs number observations used. d number indicators. p number Z-levels. convergence convergence code nlm. optim_details full output nlm.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: indicators centered row mean: \(X^c_{ik} = X_{ik} - \bar{X}_{\cdot}\), eliminates latent factor \(Y\). structural interpretation, \(E[X^c_i | Z = z_j] = \alpha_i \beta_j\) \(\alpha_i\) \(\beta_j\) identifiable nuisance parameters. test \((d-1)(p-2)\) degrees freedom. full model (Equation 3 paper) \(d \times p\) moment conditions \(2d + p - 2\) free parameters (\(d\) intercepts, \(d\) alphas, \(p-1\) betas, minus 1 alpha-beta scale indeterminacy), giving \(dp - (2d+p-2) = (d-1)(p-2)\) degrees freedom. procedure uses two-step efficient GMM: first fixed weight matrix initial estimates, efficient weight matrix.

title: T1 Test: Reliability-Independent Test of Structural Interpretation (Section 3.3) — test_t1
text: VanderWeele, T. J. Vansteelandt, S. (2022). statistical test reject structural interpretation latent factor model. Journal Royal Statistical Society Series B, 84, 2032–2054.
